article.title: The War Over Prediction Markets Is Just Getting Started
article.summary:
The other insists they are just giving people access to legitimate financial markets already subject to adequate government oversight.
Once a niche financial experiment, prediction markets have rapidly become entrenched in mainstream culture, a transformation that has brought vast sums of money into play.
But critics say that prediction markets, at least in their current form, are exploitative.
Attorneys general and gambling regulators in many states say sports contracts on prediction markets should follow state gambling laws.
Federal lawmakers have also started weighing in; earlier this month, 23 Democratic senators voiced support for efforts to push prediction markets to abide by state gambling laws.

article.title: The economy grew strongly last year, but hiring stagnated. It's making the gap between the rich and everyone else worse.
article.summary:
The data is in, and last year presents an economic conundrum: Overall growth was relatively strong, but job growth was virtually nonexistent.
ZipRecruiter economist Nicole Bachaud thinks the job market could be at a "pivot point" after stronger hiring in January.
They don't have to worry as much about rising prices of necessities and slowing wage growth.
"They're also enjoying faster wage growth, while lower-income families are seeing reduced wage growth, near-zero real wage growth, and not much wealth appreciation outside of real estate, if they have that."
Lower-income wage growth surged between 2021 and 2022, but has since cooled down a lot from the late 2022 peak.

article.title: 3 Signs US Economy Will 'Get Worse,' According to Joseph Stiglitz
article.summary:
Joseph Stiglitz, a Nobel laureate and Columbia economist, said he believes the US economy would continue to weaken when speaking to CNBC about his macro outlook on Thursday.
"Not great right now, and the prospects are that we're just going to get worse," Stiglitz said of his economic outlook.
But there are a few under-the-surface details that suggest the economy isn't on a good path, Stiglitz suggested.
Bloomberg/Getty ImagesStiglitz also pointed to the push from the Trump administration to lower interest rates.
In that scenario, the economy could grow without stoking inflation, meaning the US could have room to lower interest rates more than markets expect.

Consumer spending is the biggest driver of the U.S. economy, and that trend continued in the final months of last year.
That made GDP look weaker in the early months of the year.
That subtracted from fourth-quarter growth, although much of that will be made up in the early months of 2026.

article.title: Job Searches Lengthen, Savings Dwindle for Americans
article.summary:
Joanelle Cobos (left), Clair Todd (right)Job searches are taking longer, and some Americans' savings aren't keeping up.
Wilke's experience underscores how quickly a prolonged job search can unravel someone's finances — especially for workers without much savings to fall back on.
Business Insider is speaking with workers who've found themselves at a corporate crossroads — whether due to a layoff, resignation, job search, or shifting workplace expectations.
Many Americans aren't prepared financially for unemploymentAs unemployment spells lengthen, the financial risks of a prolonged job search are rising for many Americans.
But if her job search stretches on, she knows that sense of security will gradually fade.

article.title: Oil prices: This would be a 'fair target' amid US–Iran tensions

Mish, and I want to get to that too because I know you've been watching it.
Um, you know, piled into all of the other stuff affecting inflation, we now have a potential conflict with Iran to contend with and the effect that that could have on oil prices.
So we've got oil prices that have now climbed over the past few sessions on concerns around that.
So, right now, I think $66 is a good pivotal area if you're looking at WTI oil.
I think that's a fair target.

article.title: New law on more sustainable, circular and safe batteries enters into force
article.summary:
A new law to ensure that batteries are collected, reused and recycled in Europe is entering into force today.
This will support the shift to a circular economy, increase security of supply for raw materials and energy, and enhance the EU’s strategic autonomy.
The Batteries Regulation will ensure that batteries placed on the EU single market will only be allowed to contain a restricted amount of harmful substances that are necessary.
BackgroundSince 2006, batteries and waste batteries have been regulated at EU level under the Batteries Directive.
Such exponential growth in demand for batteries will lead to an equivalent increase in demand for raw materials, hence the need to minimise their environmental impact.

article.title: AI Is Giving English Majors Some Unexpected Leverage in the Job Market
article.summary:
Pre-pandemic, the number of English majors at the university was shrinking, part of a broader decline in English across the country, he said.
But there's been a rebound, with the number of English majors rising 9% since 2021.
Courtesy of CU BoulderDerided by some as useless, the utility of the English major has long been questioned.
That means that, after years of mocking, English majors are finally getting recognized for their usefulness.
Still, it's a dreary labor market for everyone — English majors includedThere are signs of employment hope for the English majors.

article.title: What Happened to Software is Happening to Finance and Accounting
article.summary:
What happened to software is now happening to finance.
What happened to software is now happening to finance.
So I became a finance person who codes — a weird niche that turned out to be excellent preparation for what's happening right now.
If you're already deep in this: I'd love to see what you're building.
I'm thinking of putting together a mini hackathon for people building at this intersection — finance, AI, automation.

This used car has an astonishingly high price difference over a new model: around 12.3% and an average $4,038 increase.
It is clearly a very popular used car choice.

article.title: How One Couple Hit Financial Independence Living in New York City
article.summary:
The couple went from pricey New York City rent to a monthly mortgage, and, eventually, to an incredibly low housing payment when they paid off their mortgage early in 2024.
Business Insider reviewed public records filed with the New York City Register that confirm the couple's mortgage was paid off in September 2024.
Simplified investingBefore hiring a financial planner, Chang and Nathanson were saving, but without a clear plan.
Avoiding lifestyle creepEarning two professional salaries in New York City can create pressure to spend accordingly.
For Nathanson and Chang, avoiding lifestyle inflation has been central to reaching financial independence.

article.title: Iran-US tensions: What would blocking Strait of Hormuz mean for oil, LNG?
article.summary:
Whenever tensions rise between Iran and the United States, one narrow waterway moves to the centre of global attention – the Strait of Hormuz.
Iranian authorities carried out live-fire military drills in the corridor, through which about 20 percent of global oil supplies are shipped.
The EIA estimated that in 2024, 84 percent of crude oil and condensate shipments transiting the strait headed to Asian markets.
AdvertisementAny coordinated pressure on the Strait of Hormuz and Bab al-Mandab Strait would amplify risks for global shipping, energy markets and international trade.
Almost half of India’s crude oil imports and about 60 percent of its natural gas supplies move through the Strait of Hormuz.

article.title: Uber launches robotaxi support project to aid AV partners
article.summary:
Now, the ridehail giant is launching a new initiative to support its third-party robotaxi partners called Uber Autonomous Solutions.
It’s an acknowledgement that many AV developers aren’t as cash rich as Waymo, Tesla, and other leading AV developers.
Uber says this data can help its partners improve their own autonomous vehicles as they seek to scale their robotaxi business more quickly.
Essentially, Uber is telling its AV partners to stick to the important stuff — developing software to power autonomous driving — and it will take care of the rest.
The company has said it wants to use its reach and scale to help autonomous vehicles proliferate across the globe.

article.title: Leading US Research Lab Appears to Be Squeezing Out Foreign Scientists
article.summary:
One of the US government’s top scientific research labs is taking steps that could drive away foreign scientists, a shift lawmakers and sources tell WIRED could cost the country valuable expertise and damage the agency’s credibility.
The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) helps determine the frameworks underpinning everything from cybersecurity to semiconductor manufacturing.
Many of the agency’s thousands of employees, postdoctoral scientists, contractors, and guest researchers are brought in from around the world for their specialized expertise.
The staffer, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to speak to the media, says the Department of Commerce, which oversees NIST, originally pushed for banning all foreign researchers.
NIST spokesperson Rich Press said the agency would respond to the lawmakers' letter "through the appropriate channels."

Artur Widak/NurPhoto via Getty ImagesPwC, like many consulting firms, is investing heavily in engineering talent.
These files often underpin business-critical decisions, yet PwC "found that even today's modern AI was very poorly suited to managing these big enterprise spreadsheets," Wood said.
In January, PwC launched a dedicated tech engineering career track to attract more technical talent, saying it wants to become "a destination for top engineering talent."
The second reimagines professional services from scratch: "If you were to start from a blank piece of paper, what would professional services look like in an AI agent world?"

article.title: How to Hide Google’s AI Overviews From Your Search Results
article.summary:
While there’s no off switch to avoid this smorgasbord of AI tools entirely, there is one keyboard trick you can use to dodge Google’s AI Overviews for a brief respite.
It’s an option WIRED readers highlighted under a recent article about scams found in Google’s AI Overviews.
“People find Search more helpful with AI Overviews, and they're coming back to search more as a result,” a Google spokesperson tells WIRED.
The exception seems to be on Android—at least on a Google Pixel phone we tested with, using “–ai” removed AI Overviews.
When Google launched AI Overviews in 2024, it was a major turning point for the search engine.

article.title: Making frontier cybersecurity capabilities available to defenders
article.summary:
Claude Code Security, a new capability built into Claude Code on the web, is now available in a limited research preview.
Claude Code Security is intended to put this power squarely in the hands of defenders and protect code against this new category of AI-enabled attack.
How Claude Code Security worksStatic analysis—a widely deployed form of automated security testing—is typically rule-based, meaning it matches code against known vulnerability patterns.
Nothing is applied without human approval: Claude Code Security identifies problems and suggests solutions, but developers always make the call.
Claude Code Security is one step towards our goal of more secure codebases and a higher security baseline across the industry.

article.title: DeepMind's CEO says using AI can make you a genius — or hurt your critical thinking skills
article.summary:
The Google DeepMind CEO said that AI is just like the internet when it comes to learning.
In a Thursday interview with entrepreneur Varun Mayya on the sidelines of the India AI Impact Summit, the Google DeepMind CEO said that AI is just like the internet.
"With AI, if you use it in a lazy way, it will make you worse at critical thinking and so on," he said.

The AI Adams identifies itself as artificial intelligence at the start of its clips and does not appear to solicit money.
For now, the AI "Scott Adams" fight is one family's public line-drawing exercise.

article.title: The path to ubiquitous AI
article.summary:
The path to ubiquitous AIBy Ljubisa BajicMany believe AI is the real deal.
About TaalasFounded 2.5 years ago, Taalas developed a platform for transforming any AI model into custom silicon.
AI inference is the most critical computational workload that humanity has ever faced, and the one that stands to gain the most from specialization.
The Silicon Llama is aggressively quantized, combining 3-bit and 6-bit parameters, which introduces some quality degradations relative to GPU benchmarks.
Our first products, beginning with our hard-wired Llama and rapidly expanding to more capable models, eliminate high latency and cost, the core barriers to ubiquitous AI.

The selling point of generative AI models is that they look real," RadialB tells me over the phone.

article.title: Trump administration slashes mercury regulations from coal plants
article.summary:
Mercury pollution from coal plants has been tied to serious neurological problems, especially in children and babiesOn Friday the Trump administration officially rolled back a series of Biden-era environmental regulations on coal plants, including some intended to clamp down on mercury pollution.
Those earlier rules allowed power plants that burned a particularly dirty form of coal called lignite coal to emit more mercury than plants that burned other forms of the fossil fuel.
The move is the latest in a string of actions by the Trump administration to prop up what has long been viewed as a moribund coal industry in the U.S.
The administration has ordered the Department of State to run military facilities on coal power, funded renovations for coal-powered plants and even blocked plants from shutting down.
“And once again, the Trump administration is doing so at the expense of people’s health.”Coal-fired power plants are the leading source of mercury emissions in the U.S., according to the EPA.

article.title: Sony’s WH-CH720N headphones offer excellent value at full price, but right now they're a steal.
article.summary:
We've tested oodles of noise-canceling headphones and the Sony WH-CH720N might have an unfortunate name, but they're the best budget-friendly pair we've tried.
They usually offer good value when selling for the full $178 MSRP, but right now they've fallen to $95 shipped on Amazon and $100 on Best Buy.
These headphones are well-built and well-designed, with great active noise cancellation and robust sound.
Moreover, if you want a pair of over-hear wireless headphones with active noise cancellation, it's very difficult to get that in a package this affordable.
Check those stories out if you're on the hunt for wireless gaming earbuds or open earbuds.

article.title: Read the memo: Tesla rival Lucid cuts 12% of its US workforce as EV winter takes hold
article.summary:
Tesla rival Lucid is slashing its workforce as the EV winter tightens its grip.
EV startup Lucid is cutting 12% of US employees, according to an email interim CEO Marc Winterhoff sent to unaffected employees on Friday, which Business Insider has seen.
Winterhoff said the cuts would exclude hourly production employees in manufacturing, logistics, and quality.
It comes as Lucid faces a difficult environment for EV makers amid an industry-wide downturn, with EV sales plummeting industry-wide in the US following the end of the $7,500 tax credit in September.
We have implemented a 12% reduction of our U.S. workforce, excluding hourly production employees in manufacturing, logistics, and quality.

article.title: Euro boffins track lithium plume from Falcon 9 burn-up
article.summary:
The SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket that burned up over Europe last year left a massive lithium plume in its wake, say a group of scientists.
The measurements stem from a SpaceX Falcon 9 upper stage that sprung an oxygen leak about a year ago, sending it into an uncontrolled re-entry.
A single Falcon 9 upper stage, like the one that broke up over Poland and released the lithium plume, is estimated to contain 30 kg of lithium just in the alloy used in tank walls.
"The consequences of increasing pollution from re-entering space debris on radiative transfer, ozone chemistry, and aerosol microphysics remain largely unknown."
"Using the upper atmosphere as an incinerator" is a massive blind spot, McDowell told us in a discussion last year.

Orbital data centers are not something that's going to matter at scale this decade."
In February, SpaceX said its goal is to launch a "constellation of a million satellites that operate as orbital data centers."
Tech and AI companies rely on data centers to power their products, like large language models and chatbots.
Those data centers, however, can deplete water resources, strain power grids, increase pollution, and decrease the overall quality of life.

article.title: Jesse Jackson’s vision for America embraced environmental justice
article.summary:
Peggy Shepard walked into her living room on Tuesday morning when her husband told her Jesse Jackson, the civil rights titan from South Carolina, had died.
“Immediately tears started coming,” said Shepard, co-founder and executive director of WE ACT for Environmental Justice, a New York City-based nonprofit.
Jackson made environmental justice, a term Americans were largely unfamiliar with at the time, a key plank of his second presidential run.
Here's HowJackson marched with Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., transformed American politics with his two historic presidential campaigns, and inspired countless organizers — including environmental justice advocates — along the way.
Today she’s remembered as “the mother of the environmental justice movement.” Cheryl Johnson never worked directly with Jackson on environmental issues in Chicago, but the two “would have discussions on the phone,” she said.

article.title: Politicians can't ignore data centers anymore
article.summary:
National and local politicians are calling for data centers to pay their fare share of rising utility costs.
Until recently, most states have courted data centers, enticed by promises that they will create jobs and sprout long-term revenue from vacant land.
There's still about a fifth of people in the middle who don't have feelings on data centers yet, but their numbers are shrinking.
If data centers don't start footing the bill for higher energy use, voters are likely to keep turning on them.
In Virginia, home to the world's largest concentration of data centers, aka Data Center Alley, backlash has been mounting for several years.

article.title: "Climate change isn’t about AI itself, it's about progress" - 11 Bit talk Frostpunk: 1886 and questions of scale
article.summary:

Image credit: 11 bit studiosSułecki is happy to speculate on the subject.
Discussing the game's creation, 11 Bit have elsewhere tethered these events to on-going conversations about the workplace impacts of generative AI.
Frostpunk 1866 will make use of the technology, though 11 Bit have yet to specify how.
Perhaps that's something 11 Bit should investigate in the third Purpose path.

article.title: The Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling Won’t Bring Car Prices Back to Earth
article.summary:
Now, despite a US Supreme Court ruling that will nix some of those Trump tariffs, car buyers will likely get no respite.
Automakers have actually done an OK job shielding consumers from the effects of tariffs, Caldwell says.
Even as retailers have blamed tariffs for steadily rising prices of consumer goods like electronics and appliances, car prices are up just 1 percent since this time last year, the firm’s data shows.
But as the tariff regime drags on, that could change in ways that make new-car buyers even less happy.
“If cost pressures continue to build, automakers may have less room to shield shoppers from higher prices,” Caldwell says, “but for now, the broader market impact is still playing out.”

article.title: Americans oppose the tactics ICE is using to enforce immigration laws by 2:1 margin: Poll
article.summary:
By a 2-to-1 margin, Americans oppose the tactics ICE is using to enforce immigration laws, 62% to 31%.
By a 13-point margin, Americans oppose abolishing ICE, 50% to 37%.
Opinions are polarized: 7 in 10 Democrats support abolishing ICE, while 8 in 10 Republicans oppose it.
More than 4 in 10 Americans say they are "not concerned" or "concerned but not upset" over the situation in Minnesota.
Evan Vucci/APBy an 8-point margin, Americans oppose denying federal funds to so-called sanctuary cities that limit their cooperation with ICE, 46% to 38%.

article.title: Pakistan claims to have killed at least 70 militants in strikes along Afghan border
article.summary:
Pakistan claims to have killed at least 70 militants in strikes along Afghan bordertoggle caption Hedayat Shah/APKABUL, Afghanistan — Pakistan's military killed at least 70 militants in strikes along the border with Afghanistan early Sunday, targeting what it described as hideouts of Pakistani militants it blamed for recent attacks inside the country, the deputy interior minister said.
Talal Chaudhry, Pakistan's deputy interior minister, told Geo News that at least 70 militants were killed in the strikes.
Clearing rubble and burying the deadAfghanistan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs summoned Pakistan's ambassador to Kabul and handed him a note of protest over the Pakistani strikes.
Habib Ullah, a local tribal elder, said those killed in the strikes were not militants.
Hours before the Pakistani strikes, a suicide bomber targeted a security convoy in the border district of Bannu in Pakistan's northwest, killing two soldiers, including a lieutenant colonel.

article.summary:
The Trump administration on Friday formally proposed a regulation that would dramatically restrict work permits for asylum-seekers, confirming a CBS News report about a plan to upend longstanding U.S. immigration policy.
That has generally allowed asylum applicants to request a work permit 150 days after they make their claim.
But a proposed Trump administration regulation unveiled Friday would suspend the acceptance of asylum work permit applications until U.S.
CBS News revealed in June 2025 that Trump administration officials were developing a regulation to pause asylum-related work permits and impose stricter eligibility requirements for them.
Under the Trump administration, USCIS has severely tightened immigration programs, affecting broad swaths of immigrants, legal and illegal alike.

article.title: They Bet Against Trump’s Tariffs. Now They Stand to Make Millions
article.summary:
Investment firms are on track for an enormous payday after the Supreme Court of the United States (SCOTUS) struck down President Donald Trump’s signature tariff policy on Friday.
When Trump introduced sweeping tariffs on foreign goods last April, hedge funds and specialist investment firms began to bet on the possibility that the courts might rule that he had violated the law.

The prevailing uncertainty leaves the investment firms holding refund claims with a dilemma: Should they bank some winnings by flipping the claims to another buyer, or wait out the legal wrangling?

article.title: Yogi to leave for 4-day visit to Singapore, Japan today; investment diplomacy boost, industrial expansion on agenda
article.summary:
Yogi Adityanath has departed for a four-day visit to Singapore and Japan to attract investments and deepen industrial partnerships.
(File Photo)Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath will leave on Sunday evening for his four-day visit to Singapore and Japan aimed at strengthening the state’s investment diplomacy and industrial expansion.
This will be his first foreign visit after his Myanmar trip in 2017.
A key highlight of the visit will be Government-to-Business (G2B) meetings and roundtable interactions, where CM Adityanath will engage directly with the investors.
Acting in the role of the state’s CEO, he will also present Uttar Pradesh’s industrial roadmap, policy stability, and business potential.

article.title: US Supreme Court Rules Trump’s Tariffs Are Illegal
article.summary:
The United States Supreme Court has struck down President Trump’s controversial global tariffs in a 6-3 ruling.
Every lower court that had considered Trump’s use of tariffs had ruled against him.
Today, the Supreme Court has validated what we’ve been saying all along: these tariffs were unlawful from the start.
“Small businesses are rightfully worried that the Administration will respond to this legal defeat by simply reimposing the same tariff policy through other means.
Tariffs imposed under IEEPA crippled small businesses; tariffs reimposed under different statutory approaches would have the same destructive effect.

article.title: Who is Susan Rice, the former national security advisor in Trump's crosshairs?
article.summary:
President Donald Trump has demanded that Netflix remove former US ambassador and national security advisor Susan Rice from its board, stepping up his criticism of the streaming giant as it seeks to merge with Warner Bros.
Rice, who served in senior roles in the Obama and Biden administrations, recently warned companies against aligning with Trump.
In some situations, national security officials argue that knowing the person's identity is necessary to interpret and assess the intelligence information.
As UN Ambassador, Rice supported US intervention against Muammar Gaddafi.
In a 2025 column in The New York Times, Rice accused members of Trump's national security team of "reckless negligence" after they discussed sensitive national security matters on Signal.

article.title: COO's Jobs Are Especially Challenging Due to Tariff Uncertainty
article.summary:
Friday's tariff ruling has once again put America's supply-chain bosses in a bind.
"Tariffs are written in DC, and they're felt in the COO's inbox," Jason Schloetzer, a professor at Georgetown's McDonough School of Business, told Business Insider.
Many companies are still grappling with the impact of actions they took last year to cope with Trump's tariff hikes, said Rob Lalka, who teaches entrepreneurship at Tulane University.
Now, with the fate of Trump's tariffs up in the air, COOs are experiencing the kind of whiplash that can be debilitating, said Lalka, especially for those at startups and small businesses with limited resources.
Omni, which imports goods from Spain and exports to Canada, lost sales last year due to the Trump administration's tariffs, Smith said.

article.title: John Roberts’ Rebuke of Trump’s Tariffs Is Withering, Confident, and Genuinely Encouraging
article.summary:
The Supreme Court struck down Donald Trump’s sweeping “emergency” tariffs on Friday, ruling 6–3 that they far exceed what federal law allows.
In truth, Trump’s tariffs were always on shaky legal ground, no matter how confidently the White House insisted they were permissible.
But IEEPA does not mention tariffs, duties, taxes, or anything else that would hint at Congress’ desire to delegate tariff authority to the executive branch.
Roberts, joined by Gorsuch and Barrett, invoked the “major questions doctrine” to bolster their conclusion that IEEPA does not cover tariffs.
AdvertisementTrump’s Justice Department argued that the doctrine does not apply to “foreign affairs,” attempting to gerrymander a massive exception to accommodate its trade policy.
